<p><strong>China is the worlds largest</strong> consumer meat market. Meat consumption in China has increased steadily since the early 1990s. In 2021, the Chinese consumed almost 100 million tons of meat27 percent of the worlds total<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="161dd79b-f6b4-4de1-8166-364b949f5c4b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="161dd79b-f6b4-4de1-8166-364b949f5c4b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>China Agricultural Outlook Report (20222031)</em>, China Agricultural Outlook Conference, July 12, 2022; <em>OECD-FAO Agricultural Outlook 20222031</em>, OECD, June 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> and twice the total consumption in the United States.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by Anne Grimmelt, <a href="/our-people/sheng-hong">Sheng Hong</a>, <a href="/our-people/roberto-uchoa">Roberto Uchoa de Paula</a>, Cherie Zhang, and Jia Zhou.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>But per capita meat consumption in China lags that of western countries. In 2021, per capita consumption was just half that of the United States. This picture is likely to change as increasing urbanization and rising income levels make meat more available and more affordable for Chinese consumers. As more people buy more meat, the patterns of meat consumption will undoubtedly change.</p>
<p>To understand the meat purchasing and eating habits of Chinese consumers, we surveyed about one thousand of them and compared their survey results with the habits of four thousand consumers surveyed in Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The survey found a distinct and shifting profile of meat consumption in China, reflected in five trends that executives of meat companies looking to enter this market need to understand.</p>
<h2>1. The Chinese meat market is bifurcating</h2>
<p><em>More than half of Chinese consumers eat meat regularly.</em> This is consistent with US and UK meat consumption (Exhibit 1). For these consumers, meat remains central to their diet despite an overall consumer trend of spending more conservatively, according to our 2023 McKinsey China consumer report: A time of resilience.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Fifty-seven percent of Chinese consumers eat meat regularly, higher than the rates in most Western peer markets." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<!-- -->
<p><em>Slightly less than half of Chinese consumers fit the surveys category of conscious consumers,</em> that is, people committed to eating little or no meat. This result is similar to that of peer survey countries, where 40 to 60 percent of consumers are classified as conscious consumers. Many conscious consumers in China intend to reduce their meat consumption further, though not on the scale of European consumers. Few traditional meat eaters in China share that intention.</p>
<p>Conscious consumers in China are predominantly female and members of the baby boomer generation. Conscious consumers in the peer countries also are predominantly female, but they are younger and more affluent. The fact that Chinas baby boomers have embraced conscious consumption comes as no surprise. They grew up eating a traditional Chinese cuisine rich in plant-based protein, especially tofu.</p>
<p>Asked why they limit meat consumption, Chinese conscious consumers cite personal health, diet variety, and pricefactors related directly to meat products and consumer expectations of those products. Their global peers likewise focus on personal health but then offer two very different reasons: animal welfare and carbon emissions, factors related less directly to meat and more directly to social and environmental concerns (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Health concerns dominate the decision of Chinese conscious consumers to limit meat consumption." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>2. Consumer meat preferences are poised for change</h2>
<p><em>Pork dominates the meat menu in China.</em> The 57 million tons of pork consumed in China in 2021 accounted for 60 percent of total meat consumption. Most of the Chinese consumers surveyed report purchasing pork in the past montha much higher rate than for their global peers (Exhibit 3). Many Chinese consumers eat pork in three to five meals a week or even daily. Note that Chinese cuisine includes myriad ways of cooking pork and features pork in side dishes and dim sum, as well as entres.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Pork dominates meat consumption in China, unlike in peer countries." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Poultry, which is perceived as a healthier option, ranks number two on Chinas meat menu, with 25 million tons consumed in 2021. Like their global peers, more than three-quarters of the Chinese consumers surveyed report purchasing poultry in the past month. Poultry consumption grew 7 percent a year in the period from 2017 to 2021, and annual growth of 1 percent is expected to continue until 2026.</p>
<p>Beef ranks number three on Chinas meat menu, with nine million tons consumed in 2021. About two-thirds of the Chinese consumers surveyed report purchasing beef in the past month, but their purchases but do not begin to match US levels. However, beef shows strong growth potential: following annual growth of 4 percent in 201721, growth is expected to continue at 2 percent until 2026.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Highlights of meat choices by type</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Sixty percent of </strong>Chinese consumers report that pork is used in three to five meals a week, compared with 30 percent among their global peers.</p>
<p>Twenty-nine percent of Chinese consumers surveyed especially like the taste of beef.</p>
<p>Twenty percent of Chinese consumers surveyed say that they plan to spend more on beef, 12 percent plan to spend less, and 68 percent plan no change in spending. The net result of these changes would be increases of 8 percent in beef consumption and 1 percent in poultry consumption, along with a 6 percent decline in pork consumption.</p>
<p>Seafood, another promising healthy option, is expected to grow 1 to 2 percent a year until 2026.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><em>Despite its current dominance of the meat market in China, the health concerns mentioned by conscious consumers, combined with rising income levels, threaten porks market share.</em> Chinese consumers, especially those affluent enough to pay more for meat, consider beef healthier than pork. They see the higher price of beef as a sign of a premium products higher quality, and they remember the safety issues that have historically been associated with pork. Twenty-eight percent of the Chinese consumers surveyed say they plan to reduce their pork consumption (see sidebar, Highlights of meat choices by type).</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Twenty-eight percent of the Chinese consumers surveyed say they plan to reduce their pork consumption.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Our <em>2023 McKinsey China consumer report </em>finds the number of top-earning households increasing rapidly. Today, they account for 39 percent of urban households and 55 percent of urban household consumption (Exhibit 4). By 2025, they will account for more than half of Chinas urban households. These consumers stand to have significant influence on meat consumption patterns.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The number of high- and upper-middle-income households in China is growing and will surpass 50 percent of households by 2025." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>3. Product safety and taste govern meat-purchasing decisions</h2>
<p><em>When buying meat, Chinese consumers look, first and foremost, for healthiness and product safety and for quality and taste. </em>While the emphasis on these buying factors is undoubtedly related to consumers growing health concerns, it may also reflect a history of incidents involving meat safety and quality, along with questions about the adequacy of standards in the Chinese meat industry. In addition, the diversity of regional cuisines and cooking methods across China keeps taste top of mind (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Product safety and taste govern buying choices in China, while price dominates decisions in peer countries." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Affordability ranks a distant third. This is a far cry from the overwhelming attention paid to price in the peer countries studied. In these other countries, price increases and inflation are running rampant, with inflation at four times the rate in China.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="991ebd85-3859-4606-8c8a-1f5df5bbf351"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="991ebd85-3859-4606-8c8a-1f5df5bbf351" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Oxford Economics, accessed summer 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<h2>4. Demand for convenience is reshaping meat consumption patterns</h2>
<p>Growing demand for convenience is shaping new patterns of meat consumption in China.</p>
<p><em>The Chinese consumers surveyed report purchasing more prepared meat to eat at home.</em> Like their global peers, Chinese consumers mostly buy uncooked meat for at-home consumption. But as younger consumers exert more purchasing power, convenience looms larger as a key buying factor. These consumers typically feel great work pressure and have little time to cook, so they express interest in prepared meat (precooked or fried) and ready-to-eat meals delivered to their homes.</p>
<p><em>Chinese consumers also report spending more money to eat meat in restaurants,</em> in contrast to consumers in the peer survey countries, who spend more on meat to eat at home. Chinese restaurants typically use frozen meat, so the growth of the restaurant and catering market (8 percent year over year in 201823) promises to increase consumption of frozen meat.</p>
<p>According to our survey, 80 percent of meat purchases happen offline, with half of those purchases made in the traditional wet market. But market trends hint at growth to come. </p>
<p><em>Online purchasing appeals to consumers demanding convenience. </em>Chinese consumers are extremely tech-savvy. Long-standing smartphone ownership has fostered a dynamic digital-commerce marketplace. Consumers already show considerable willingness to buy meat online, and many intend to increase their online purchasing.</p>
<p>Why? The top reasons consumers give to explain their use of online channels include time savings, direct delivery, pandemic-induced desire to avoid human contact, and greater product selection. The pandemic saw online sales of fresh food more than double, from 15 percent to 33 percent, and that shift looks likely to stick postpandemic. </p>
<p>China is well positioned to handle the growth of online meat sales. The necessary infrastructure, including logistics networks and cold chain technology, is firmly established. The number of online fresh-grocery players is increasing. And lower-income consumers are embracing the concept.</p>
<h2>5. Sustainability is gaining awareness but little influence</h2>
<p><em>Consumer awareness of sustainability is increasing in China but does not translate into enthusiasm for alternative meat</em>. Promotion of sustainability benefits by meat producers and brands has made Chinese consumers aware of sustainability; many pay attention to sustainability claims when buying meat. This is consistent with consumer awareness in the United Kingdom and the United States but lags behind awareness in Germany. Increasing wealth and sophistication in China also encourage openness to new food concepts.</p>
<p>Across the markets surveyed, the sustainability claims that resonate most strongly with consumers relate directly to meat and personal health: pasture raised or free range and antibiotic free. Claims related to animal welfare (grass fed) weigh heavily with fewer consumers. Even fewer pay much attention to claims related only indirectly to meat (Exhibit 6).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Antibiotic-free and pasture-raised claims have the greatest impact on consumers across the countries surveyed." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/consumer%20packaged%20goods/our%20insights/for%20love%20of%20meat%20five%20trends%20in%20china%20that%20meat%20executives%20must%20grasp/svgz-chinameat-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Despite growing awareness of sustainability and the emerging desire to reduce meat consumption, alternative meat has gained little traction in China. Only 6 percent of the consumers surveyed report purchasing alternative meat in the past month, versus 30 to 40 percent of their global peers. More than 70 percent of Chinese consumers report rarely or never consuming alternative meat, versus 40 percent of their global peers.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>More than 70 percent of Chinese consumers report rarely or never consuming alternative meat, versus 40 percent of their global peers.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>One factor in this limited uptake may be that Chinese consumers lack awareness of the impact of meat consumption on climate changea hot topic in Western countries. But Chinese consumers also express strong reservations about alternative meat products. Almost 80 percent dislike the taste of these products, and about 20 percent object to their price. Almost half report having little knowledge of the products nutritional value and considerable concern about additives. All these factors contribute to forecasts of limited demand for alternative meat in China.</p>
<h2>Strategic implications for global meat players</h2>
<p>Chinas huge population and growing middle class suggest significant market demand for real meat over the next decade. The market is expected to grow 1 percent year over year between 2022 and 2026. To capture a meaningful share of this market, global meat players should set entry strategies that reflect insights into Chinese meat consumption.</p>
<p><em>Companies can explore potential white spaces for establishing competitive advantage.</em> As Chinese consumers shift meat consumption from pork to protein sources considered to be of higher quality, global players have an opportunity to introduce more premium offerings, especially beef, to the market. Likewise, as convenience-obsessed consumers eat more meals in restaurants, global players have an opportunity to meet the growing demand for frozen meat.</p>
<p>Global players typically have more advanced farming capabilities and operational excellence than local players and may be able to leverage cost efficiency as a competitive advantage. At the same time, global players should carefully consider whether to partner with local players, who would be the best partners, and how a partnership would fit into the broader China operating model. Typically, partnering with midsize local players can help global players enter the market with a relatively limited investment.</p>
<p><em>Companies can consider how they might shape the go-to-market strategy and product portfolio to meet consumers demand for convenience.</em> While local producers are likely to continue providing the lions share of uncooked meat to consumers, global players might focus on the emerging market for prepared meat products. Success would require targeting and marketing to younger consumers, especially those who are more affluent.</p>
<p>Global players should embrace the online sales channel. This channel, which already accounts for 5 to 10 percent of meat sales, is relatively advanced in China. The offline channel is fragmented and requires local resources, but the online channel is open for global business and is better suited to the branded, premium products that global players would bring.</p>
<p><em>Finally, companies may find attractive opportunities in tailoring value propositions to consumer concerns about health and sustainability</em>. Beyond communicating the health and sustainability benefits of products, global players should ensure that their products deliver on those promisesfor example, by improving product safety.</p>
<p>Global players looking to anchor their strategy in concepts new to Chinese consumers, such as the health benefits of alternative meat or the role of animal welfare in sustainability, will have to recognize the limited awareness and understanding of these concepts among consumers, especially those living outside of major cities. Success would require investing significant time and resources to educate targeted consumers and build the market for relevant products. Making these efforts context specificfor example, linking new plant-based protein products to Chinas long history of eating tofumight greatly enhance the odds of success.</p>
<hr>
<p>Protein will not disappear from consumers diets. The question is, how will they consume it, and how will they make that decision? Accurate answers to this question can give global players an advantage in serving Chinas consumers.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Anne Grimmelt</strong> is a senior expert in McKinseys Stamford, Connecticut, office; <strong><a href="/our-people/sheng-hong">Sheng Hong</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Shenzhen office; <strong><a href="/our-people/roberto-uchoa">Roberto Uchoa de Paula</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Chicago office; <strong>Cherie Zhang</strong> is a knowledge expert in the Shanghai office; and <strong>Jia Zhou</strong> is a partner in the Beijing office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Jordan Bar Am, Ariel Hsieh, Yunzhi Li, Karl Nilsson, Amy Yang, Ellen Zhang, and Emily Zhao for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section Meat consumption in China has increased steadily since the early 1990s. In 2021, per capita consumption was just half that of the United States. This picture is likely to change as increasing urbanization and rising income levels make meat more available and more affordable for Chinese consumers. As more people buy more meat, the patterns of meat consumption will undoubtedly change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo understand the meat purchasing and eating habits of Chinese consumers, we surveyed about one thousand of them and compared their survey results with the habits of four thousand consumers surveyed in Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The Chinese meat market is bifurcating\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMore than half of Chinese consumers eat meat regularly.\u003c/em\u003e This is consistent with US and UK meat consumption (Exhibit 1). For these consumers, meat remains central to their diet despite an overall consumer trend of spending more conservatively, according to our 2023 McKinsey China consumer report: A time of resilience.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSlightly less than half of Chinese consumers fit the survey\u0026rsquo;s category of \u0026ldquo;conscious consumers,\u0026rdquo;\u003c/em\u003e that is, people committed to eating little or no meat. This result is similar to that of peer survey countries, where 40 to 60 percent of consumers are classified as conscious consumers. Many conscious consumers in China intend to reduce their meat consumption further, though not on the scale of European consumers. Few traditional meat eaters in China share that intention.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConscious consumers in China are predominantly female and members of the baby boomer generation. Conscious consumers in the peer countries also are predominantly female, but they are younger and more affluent. The fact that China\u0026rsquo;s baby boomers have embraced conscious consumption comes as no surprise. They grew up eating a traditional Chinese cuisine rich in plant-based protein, especially tofu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsked why they limit meat consumption, Chinese conscious consumers cite personal health, diet variety, and price\u0026mdash;factors related directly to meat products and consumer expectations of those products. Consumer meat preferences are poised for change\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003ePork dominates the meat menu in China.\u003c/em\u003e The 57 million tons of pork consumed in China in 2021 accounted for 60 percent of total meat consumption. Most of the Chinese consumers surveyed report purchasing pork in the past month\u0026mdash;a much higher rate than for their global peers (Exhibit 3). Many Chinese consumers eat pork in three to five meals a week or even daily. Note that Chinese cuisine includes myriad ways of cooking pork and features pork in side dishes and dim sum, as well as entr\u0026eacute;es.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003ePoultry, which is perceived as a healthier option, ranks number two on China\u0026rsquo;s meat menu, with 25\u0026nbsp;million tons consumed in 2021. Poultry consumption grew 7\u0026nbsp;percent a year in the period from 2017 to 2021, and annual growth of 1 percent is expected to continue until 2026.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeef ranks number three on China\u0026rsquo;s meat menu, with nine million tons consumed in 2021. However, beef shows strong growth potential: following annual growth of 4 percent in 2017\u0026ndash;21, growth is expected to continue at 2\u0026nbsp;percent until 2026.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDespite its current dominance of the meat market in China, the health concerns mentioned by conscious consumers, combined with rising income levels, threaten pork\u0026rsquo;s market share.\u003c/em\u003e Chinese consumers, especially those affluent enough to pay more for meat, consider beef healthier than pork. They see the higher price of beef as a sign of a premium product\u0026rsquo;s higher quality, and they remember the safety issues that have historically been associated with pork. By 2025, they will account for more than half of China\u0026rsquo;s urban households. These consumers stand to have significant influence on meat consumption patterns.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch2\u003e3. Product safety and taste govern meat-purchasing decisions\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen buying meat, Chinese consumers look, first and foremost, for healthiness and product safety and for quality and taste. \u003c/em\u003eWhile the emphasis on these buying factors is undoubtedly related to consumers\u0026rsquo; growing health concerns, it may also reflect a history of incidents involving meat safety and quality, along with questions about the adequacy of standards in the Chinese meat industry. In addition, the diversity of regional cuisines and cooking methods across China keeps taste top of mind (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eAffordability ranks a distant third. This is a far cry from the overwhelming attention paid to price in the peer countries studied. In these other countries, price increases and inflation are running rampant, with inflation at four times the rate in China.[[Footnote 2]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e4. Demand for convenience is reshaping meat consumption patterns\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGrowing demand for convenience is shaping new patterns of meat consumption in China.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Chinese consumers surveyed report purchasing more prepared meat to eat at home.\u003c/em\u003e Like their global peers, Chinese consumers mostly buy uncooked meat for at-home consumption. But as younger consumers exert more purchasing power, convenience looms larger as a key buying factor. These consumers typically feel great work pressure and have little time to cook, so they express interest in prepared meat (precooked or fried) and ready-to-eat meals delivered to their homes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eChinese consumers also report spending more money to eat meat in restaurants,\u003c/em\u003e in contrast to consumers in the peer survey countries, who spend more on meat to eat at home. Chinese restaurants typically use frozen meat, so the growth of the restaurant and catering market (8 percent year over year in 2018\u0026ndash;23) promises to increase consumption of frozen meat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to our survey, 80 percent of meat purchases happen offline, with half of those purchases made in the traditional wet market. But market trends hint at growth to come. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOnline purchasing appeals to consumers demanding convenience. \u003c/em\u003eChinese consumers are extremely tech-savvy. Long-standing smartphone ownership has fostered a dynamic digital-commerce marketplace. Consumers already show considerable willingness to buy meat online, and many intend to increase their online purchasing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhy? The top reasons consumers give to explain their use of online channels include time savings, direct delivery, pandemic-induced desire to avoid human contact, and greater product selection. The pandemic saw online sales of fresh food more than double, from 15 percent to 33 percent, and that shift looks likely to stick postpandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChina is well positioned to handle the growth of online meat sales. The necessary infrastructure, including logistics networks and cold chain technology, is firmly established. The number of online fresh-grocery players is increasing. And lower-income consumers are embracing the concept.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e5. Sustainability is gaining awareness but little influence\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumer awareness of sustainability is increasing in China but does not translate into enthusiasm for alternative meat\u003c/em\u003e. Promotion of sustainability benefits by meat producers and brands has made Chinese consumers aware of sustainability; many pay attention to sustainability claims when buying meat. This is consistent with consumer awareness in the United Kingdom and the United States but lags behind awareness in Germany. Increasing wealth and sophistication in China also encourage openness to new food concepts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross the markets surveyed, the sustainability claims that resonate most strongly with consumers relate directly to meat and personal health: pasture raised or free range and antibiotic free. Claims related to animal welfare (grass fed) weigh heavily with fewer consumers. Even fewer pay much attention to claims related only indirectly to meat (Exhibit 6).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eDespite growing awareness of sustainability and the emerging desire to reduce meat consumption, alternative meat has gained little traction in China. Only 6 percent of the consumers surveyed report purchasing alternative meat in the past month, versus 30\u0026nbsp;to 40 percent of their global peers. More than 70\u0026nbsp;percent of Chinese consumers report rarely or never consuming alternative meat, versus 40\u0026nbsp;percent of their global peers.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eOne factor in this limited uptake may be that Chinese consumers lack awareness of the impact of meat consumption on climate change\u0026mdash;a hot topic in Western countries. But Chinese consumers also express strong reservations about alternative meat products. Almost 80 percent dislike the taste of these products, and about 20 percent object to their price. Almost half report having little knowledge of the products\u0026rsquo; nutritional value and considerable concern about additives. All these factors contribute to forecasts of limited demand for alternative meat in China.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eStrategic implications for global meat players\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChina\u0026rsquo;s huge population and growing middle class suggest significant market demand for real meat over the next decade. The market is expected to grow 1 percent year over year between 2022 and 2026. To capture a meaningful share of this market, global meat players should set entry strategies that reflect insights into Chinese meat consumption.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCompanies can explore potential white spaces for establishing competitive advantage.\u003c/em\u003e As Chinese consumers shift meat consumption from pork to protein sources considered to be of higher quality, global players have an opportunity to introduce more premium offerings, especially beef, to the market. Likewise, as convenience-obsessed consumers eat more meals in restaurants, global players have an opportunity to meet the growing demand for frozen meat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobal players typically have more advanced farming capabilities and operational excellence than local players and may be able to leverage cost efficiency as a competitive advantage. At the same time, global players should carefully consider whether to partner with local players, who would be the best partners, and how a partnership would fit into the broader China operating model. Typically, partnering with midsize local players can help global players enter the market with a relatively limited investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCompanies can consider how they might shape the go-to-market strategy and product portfolio to meet consumers\u0026rsquo; demand for convenience.\u003c/em\u003e While local producers are likely to continue providing the lion\u0026rsquo;s share of uncooked meat to consumers, global players might focus on the emerging market for prepared meat products. Success would require targeting and marketing to younger consumers, especially those who are more affluent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobal players should embrace the online sales channel. This channel, which already accounts for 5 to 10 percent of meat sales, is relatively advanced in China. The offline channel is fragmented and requires local resources, but the online channel is open for global business and is better suited to the branded, premium products that global players would bring.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eFinally, companies may find attractive opportunities in tailoring value propositions to consumer concerns about health and sustainability\u003c/em\u003e. Beyond communicating the health and sustainability benefits of products, global players should ensure that their products deliver on those promises\u0026mdash;for example, by improving product safety.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobal players looking to anchor their strategy in concepts new to Chinese consumers, such as the health benefits of alternative meat or the role of animal welfare in sustainability, will have to recognize the limited awareness and understanding of these concepts among consumers, especially those living outside of major cities. Success would require investing significant time and resources to educate targeted consumers and build the market for relevant products. Making these efforts context specific\u0026mdash;for example, linking new plant-based protein products to China\u0026rsquo;s long history of eating tofu\u0026mdash;might greatly enhance the odds of success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProtein will not disappear from consumers\u0026rsquo; diets. The question is, how will they consume it, and how will they make that decision? Accurate answers to this question can give global players an advantage in serving China\u0026rsquo;s consumers.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
